Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Macroscopic Dynamics of Ultrasonic Consolidation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to identify and mitigate the mechanisms responsible for bond degradation in the Ultrasonic Consolidation manufacturing process. To achieve this objective, a multi-level research framework that combines theories of non-smooth systems dynamics with computational algorithms and a specially-developed experimental module will be used. At the first level, Hamilton's principle is combined with a Rayleigh-Ritz approach to develop a reduced-order model, which describes the build feature's response to ultrasonic excitations. At the second level, mathematical models are derived to describe the stick-slip response of the feature due to frictional interactions. The derived models are then experimentally validated and combined to understand how changes in the build feature's geometry and material properties influence stresses and subsequent interface bonding. The knowledge is used to devise strategies to mitigate bond degradation.

If successful, this endeavor will provide the necessary tools to overcome a hurdle that is preventing the broad use of the promising Ultrasonic Consolidation manufacturing process. By providing a mechanism to bond dissimilar materials, and embed electronics and fiber reinforcements in metallic structures, Ultrasonic Consolidation permits manufacturing machine components and structural systems with unique performance capabilities. This includes functionally-graded structures, metal-matrix composites, fiber embedded adaptive systems, and self-sensing components that are essential for the health-monitoring of machines and structures. Research results will also be widely published to enable students and engineers to see the critical link between dynamics and manufacturing. An educational outreach initiative that integrates research with education through exciting activities is also planned to promote diversity through recruitment of minority students.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ultrasonic Consolidation (UC) is a new additive manufacturing process that merges ultrasonic joining of thin metal foils with contour milling. UC has several key advantages over other additive manufacturing methods. For instance, UC permits bonding metals at half their fusion temperature which has the effect of reducing thermal gradients in the material that can lead to distortion and brittleness. Moreover, UC can be easily utilized to join both similar and dissimilar materials that are hazardous in powder form such as Ti, Al, and Mg without the use of inert gas shielding; and allows for bonding of materials that contain tenacious oxide layers, such as Aluminum 3003, without the need for additional preprocessing manufacturing technologies.

 

Nevertheless, UC has demonstrated a critical shortcoming in its operation. Specifically, the process has an upper limit on build height commonly called the height-to-width problem. During the build process, as the height of the build feature approaches the width, additional layers cannot be bonded to the feature and this is seemingly independent of the length. Through this award, we have shown that the complex dynamic interactions between the high-frequency excitations of the sonotrode and the build feature are responsible for bond degradation at these width-to-height ratios.  We built several analytical and numerical models to demonstrate that the loss of bonding is due to resonant interactions between the excitation and the infinite modal frequencies of the build feature. At a certain height-to-width ratio, these resonant interactions are initiated; influencing, in a complex manner, the frictional stresses at the interface between the sonotrode and the feature and causing the build feature to undergo complex dynamic responses characterized by discontinuous and non-smooth stick and stick-slip motions. Such motions were shown to be the main factor behind bond failure.  Using the resulting models and attained understanding, we proposed and implemented several approaches to overcome the height-to-width problem.

 

By overcoming this critical issue and since UC permits joining dissimilar materials and allows for embedding objects such as delicate fibers within a three dimensional metal structure; UC can now be successfully utilized to embed electronics (sensors and actuators) into armored panels for vehicles, to build metallic smart structures, to produce injection molding tools, and to fabricate lightweight structural panels for satellites. The potential market is expected to grow even further as the emphasis on mass customization creates a need to fabricate one-off parts. 

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2016
Modified by: Mohammed F Daqaq
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Ultrasonic Consolidation (UC) is a new additive manufacturing process that merges ultrasonic joining of thin metal foils with contour milling. UC has several key advantages over other additive manufacturing methods. For instance, UC permits bonding metals at half their fusion temperature which has the effect of reducing thermal gradients in the material that can lead to distortion and brittleness. Moreover, UC can be easily utilized to join both similar and dissimilar materials that are hazardous in powder form such as Ti, Al, and Mg without the use of inert gas shielding; and allows for bonding of materials that contain tenacious oxide layers, such as Aluminum 3003, without the need for additional preprocessing manufacturing technologies. Nevertheless, UC has demonstrated a critical shortcoming in its operation. Specifically, the process has an upper limit on build height commonly called the height-to-width problem. During the build process, as the height of the build feature approaches the width, additional layers cannot be bonded to the feature and this is seemingly independent of the length. Through this award, we have shown that the complex dynamic interactions between the high-frequency excitations of the sonotrode and the build feature are responsible for bond degradation at these width-to-height ratios. We built several analytical and numerical models to demonstrate that the loss of bonding is due to resonant interactions between the excitation and the infinite modal frequencies of the build feature. At a certain height-to-width ratio, these resonant interactions are initiated; influencing, in a complex manner, the frictional stresses at the interface between the sonotrode and the feature and causing the build feature to undergo complex dynamic responses characterized by discontinuous and non-smooth stick and stick-slip motions. Such motions were shown to be the main factor behind bond failure. Using the resulting models and attained understanding, we proposed and implemented several approaches to overcome the height-to-width problem. By overcoming this critical issue and since UC permits joining dissimilar materials and allows for embedding objects such as delicate fibers within a three dimensional metal structure; UC can now be successfully utilized to embed electronics (sensors and actuators) into armored panels for vehicles, to build metallic smart structures, to produce injection molding tools, and to fabricate lightweight structural panels for satellites. The potential market is expected to grow even further as the emphasis on mass customization creates a need to fabricate one-off parts. Last Modified: 06/29/2016 Submitted by: Mohammed F Daqaq
